data.title: Simón (2023)
data.meta_description: Simón, a Venezuelan freedom fighter exiled in Miami, copes not only with trauma, but also deep guilt over a choice he must make: stay in Miami and start a new life, or return home to the losing fight against a tyrannical regime.
data.text:
Valoro más la película por su aporte artístico que por su mensaje. Ojo, eso no quiere decir que su mensaje sea malo o que no sea lo suficientemente contundente y crudo, sino por el contrario, como venezolano, aún me toca en fibras incómodas y recientes que todavía no han terminado de sanar.

Esta película está llena de tensión, de impotencia, pero sobretodo, de culpas. Es una cita obligatoria por ser una excelente muestra del cine nacional y su potencial, pero más aún, es una cita obligatoria por la cachetada que te da mientras te recuerda: ¿Qué hiciste tú durante las protestas de 2017?

A pretty intriguing and tense drama about a former Venezuelan man who escaped from the country after being tortured for his participation in a student riot because of the political and social situation still happening in the country. Now living in Miami, he’s struggling with guilt and also tries to help those he left behind.

The direction is really good. The story is great, mainly the flashback, though the present stuff is pretty good. Christian’s performance is really strong, as he conveys every emotion that consumes Simon. That scene in the police department was probably one of the highlights. The cinematography is also pretty good, as is the score.

All in all, a really good film about a topic (or at least in a country) that’s rarely discussed. A very (unfortunate) timely film not only because the different wars and political turmoil taking place around the world, but the recent elections.
